awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: TRAIN (TRansfer to Interdisciplinary Natural sciences): A Community College-University Consortium to Increase Community College Transfer and Success
awd_abstract_narration:
The TRAnsfer to Interdisciplinary Natural sciences (TRAIN) program supports students from community college through graduation from Arizona State University's New College.  TRAIN students begin with scholarships and a robust set of support structures at the community college, which follow them seamlessly through transfer to ASU.  Students are recruited from Phoenix, South Mountain, and Glendale Community Colleges (all HSIs), where approximately 85% identify as individuals traditionally underrepresented in STEM.   In addition to scholarship support, students benefit from engagement with faculty mentors, specialized advising, peer mentoring, tutoring, research experiences, and participation in cohort-based activities.  Authentic, career-focused experiences underpin the cohort formation; students are offered various opportunities, such as undergraduate research, internships, volunteer opportunities and field trips.  Students blog about these authentic experiences, relating them to their educational and career development.  Weekly blog comments by students and faculty mentors keep the cohort connected and help to develop a robust peer-teaching and support network. 
                
The TRAIN program will add to the collective knowledge in STEM education by utilizing a value-added model of programmatic analysis which will analyze the unique challenges faced by students underrepresented in STEM, and determine how interventions and support structures impact diverse students differently.  A cost/benefit analysis of the support structures by sub-population will be undertaken and an analysis conducted to determine which yield the best returns on investment.  Broader impacts of TRAIN include the construction, evaluation and improved understanding of an innovative transfer pipeline between the nation's largest public university and one of its largest community college systems featuring several HSIs. This project could transform how community college students are supported during the attrition-prone transfer from two-year to four-year institutions.

por.por_cntn:
The major objective of the S-STEM TRAIN initiative at GCC was the synthesis of a cohesive scholar group to provide a sense of belonging and shared identity, establishing a solid foundation for academic success. This involved implementing best practices in the support of scholarship receiving community college students, to facilitate their academic persistence and graduation or transfer to a four-year school. Students were encouraged to participate in grant sponsored STEM projects and received mentoring and personalized education plans, financial aid advising, transfer or career planning, and upon enrollment joined a thriving cohort of S-STEM alumni.

78 students in total participated in the Glendale Community College (GCC) contingent of the program over the 6-year duration of the grant (which included a one year no cost extension due to the COVID interruptions). Along with the other benefits of the program, students participated in mentored STEM projects. At GCC, as part of this Authentic Experience, students received thorough lab training with new students mentored by more experienced students. This conferred numerous benefits on mentee and mentor alike and evolved into a very effective way of training contemporary life science laboratory skills. All recipients also participated in the online cohort, as did their counterparts in our partner schools, and developed and posted a web log detailing their research activities. A tangible growth of student capabilities and confidence was observed and quantified by the 3 peer reviewed research papers and 28 conference presentations prepared by GCC TRAIN scholars over the period of the grant.

The TRAIN program supported a generation of knowledge component in the form of a research study comparing outcomes for S-STEM scholars compared to a matched control group and student academic performance and satisfaction were evaluated during the life of the project. Almost 100% of S-STEM scholars successfully completed 12 or more semester credit hours with a GPA of 3.0 or greater. Cohort retention and graduation/transfer rates were superior to matched students. Semester over semester persistence was typically greater than 80%. Furthermore, 80% of GCC TRAIN scholars surveyed said they were extremely satisfied with their overall S-STEM experience while 20% said they were somewhat satisfied. All program specific components were rated extremely positively by GCC TRAIN students, with all those surveyed expressing themselves as being extremely or somewhat satisfied with almost every component. The only exceptions were dissatisfaction with transfer information among 75% of responding students, and with graduation information among a minority of students. The critical importance to GCC TRAIN scholars of personal interactions, mentoring, and advising was very pronounced in all student surveys.

With regard to transferring to a four-year school, a significant finding of this study was that students were anxious about a range of factors, and these hampered their transition to University. These factors included credit transferability, loss of financial aid, family and cultural barriers and unfamiliar academic expectations. It appeared very likely that stronger advising, financial planning support, and structured transfer pathways could help mitigate these risks and improve transfer student success. The complete findings of this research were compiled and published in a detailed study published in  the Community College Journal of Research and Practice (Sandrin et al., https://doi.org/10.1080/10668926.2023.2256249)

 


Last Modified: 03/04/2025
Modified by: James Tuohy
